author: By Maggie Astor
title: Offering Few Details, Trump Says He Knows How Republicans Should Approach Abortion
description: The former president suggested that Republicans needed to talk about exceptions to abortion bans but was otherwise vague about how his party should discuss the issue.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump acknowledged this week that Republican positions on abortion were hurting the party, but offered few details after claiming he knew how to thread the needle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman and Lanna Apisukh
title: After Fox News, Geraldo Rivera Boats Into the Sunset (via Cleveland)
description: At 80 years old, the longtime television personality found himself unexpectedly unemployed after more than half a century. So he steered his boat toward the Erie Canal, seeking one last adventure.
content: The 36-foot luxury motorboat, with its polished mahogany hull and American flag waving from the stern, set off from East Hampton on a recent Sunday morning, heading toward the tip of downtown Manhattan and passing beneath airplanes, bridges, thunderstorms and, eventually, a glorious blue sky. The trip would take the boat, named Belle, within view of the Statue of Liberty en route to the Hudson River and, finally, Lake Erie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: How to Help Hurricane Idalia Victims
description: Here’s how to connect with verified aid groups working in the areas affected by the storm.
content: Hurricane Idalia made landfall in Florida on Wednesday, causing devastating flooding. It then moved on to bring surging water into Charleston, S.C., before heading toward North Carolina on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Cats With Bird Flu? The Threat Grows.
description: But not enough is being done to stop it.
content: The global H5N1 avian flu outbreak, already devastating wild birds and poultry, keeps spreading to mammals, bringing it one step closer to a potential human outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
title: Proud Boys Lieutenant Sentenced to 17 Years in Jan. 6 Sedition Case
description: The penalty for Joseph Biggs is the second longest in more than 1,100 criminal cases stemming from the Capitol attack. Another Proud Boys leader was sentenced to 15 years.
content: Two leaders of the Proud Boys were sentenced to lengthy prison terms on Thursday for their roles in the assault on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with a top lieutenant in the far-right group, Joseph Biggs, given 17 years, and another key figure in the attack, Zachary Rehl, getting 15 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Justice Thomas Defended Himself Over Ethics Questions
description: Also, a deadly fire in Johannesburg. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: In an unusual move, Justice Clarence Thomas attached to his annual financial disclosure form released today a response to reports that he had failed to disclose luxury trips, flights on a private jet and a real estate transaction with a Texas billionaire who has donated to conservative causes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Why Biden Can’t Expedite Work Permits for Migrants
description: Congress is unwilling to change entrenched immigration laws. Other options face lawsuits or backlogs that could lead to even longer waits.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York has blamed the White House for failing to respond to her call to expedite work permits for the influx of migrants arriving in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Whipple
title: Mark Meadows Is a Warning About a Second Trump Term
description: His failure is a template for the inevitable disasters if Trump returns to the White House.
content: On Monday, Mark Meadows, a former White House chief of staff, testified in an effort to move the Georgia racketeering case against his former boss Donald Trump and co-defendants to federal court. On the stand, he said that he believed his actions regarding the 2020 election fell within the scope of his job as a federal official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: This Tiny Snake Has a Big Mouth
description: New research indicates that, relative to their size, the snakes that can gulp down the largest meals are harmless and three feet long.
content: Snakes can’t really unhinge their jaws, but for some, that doesn’t get in the way of swallowing absurdly large prey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Man Gets 2 Years in Prison for Spending Pandemic Money on Alpaca Farm
description: Dana L. McIntyre, who owned a pizzeria in a Boston suburb, defrauded the federal government out of more than $660,000, the Justice Department said.
content: When the coronavirus pandemic slowed business at Dana L. McIntyre’s already flailing Boston-area pizzeria in early 2020, he, like millions of other Americans, applied for pandemic relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: Trump, Waiving Arraignment, Pleads Not Guilty in Georgia Case
description: The 19 defendants in the election interference case are sparring with prosecutors over when a trial might start, and whether it will be in state or federal court.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump pleaded not guilty on Thursday and waived his arraignment in the Georgia criminal case charging him and 18 of his allies with interfering in the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘The Mountain’ Review: Stone-Faced in Nature’s Splendors
description: In this drama directed by and starring Thomas Salvador, an urbanite plunges into treacherous conditions.
content: Thomas Salvador’s “The Mountain” is a lightweight parable about a man who abandons modernity to connect with the earth. On impulse, a Parisian robotics engineer named Pierre (Salvador, who also wrote the script with Naïla Guiguet), extends a work trip to scale France’s snow-capped Mont Blanc. “I can’t resist,” he says, and for a while the film plays like a silent comedy about a transcendence junkie itching for a fix. Pierre’s cable car is too crowded, his new ice crampons look silly alongside other tourists in tees, his scenic glacier-top tent is hemmed-in by more tents. Nevertheless, he prefers not to rejoin civilization — he’s Bartleby the Backpacker, holding out for something he can’t explain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: A Time Capsule Appeared to Be Full of Dirt. Then, They Looked Closer.
description: The nearly 200-year-old capsule appeared to contain little of value when it was unveiled Monday during a livestream from the U.S. Military Academy. An archaeologist later found six coins and a medal inside.
content: The unveiling of a nearly 200-year-old time capsule yielded great disappointment earlier this week, when the box — opened at the U.S. Military Academy in West Point, N.Y., during a livestream watched by thousands — appeared to contain only dirt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Decoding the Complicated Color Wheel of Wines
description: Once, the significant decision was red or white? Now, consumers face a much more challenging spectrum of selections. It’s a great thing.
content: Wine seems both deceptively simple and unrelentingly complicated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: David Rowland, Who Won Back Looted Art for Jewish Heirs, Dies at 67
description: As a lawyer, he worked on behalf of the families of Jews who had been persecuted by the Nazis to recover artworks, some housed in pre-eminent museums.
content: David Rowland, a lawyer who secured the recovery of hundreds of looted artworks for the heirs of Jewish collectors who had been persecuted by the Nazis, challenging some of the world’s leading museums in doing so, died on Aug. 15 at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Matt Stevens
title: Starfield’s 1,000 Planets May Be One Giant Leap for Game Design
description: The stakes are high for Bethesda’s newest role-playing game. Microsoft needs an Xbox hit, and players are hungry for an expansive and satisfying space adventure.
content: Starfield almost immediately nudges its players to the edges of the cosmos. In the opening hours of the role-playing video game, it’s possible to land your spaceship on Earth’s moon or zip 16 light-years to Alpha Centauri. When you open your map and zoom out from a planet, you can behold its surrounding solar system; zoom out again, and you’re scrolling past luminous stars and the mysterious worlds that orbit them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Review: ‘Next to Normal’ Is Back, With Extra Pathos
description: A London revival of the hit musical brings extra warmth to the story of a woman in psychological free fall.
content: A mind in torment is making for some terrific theater at the moment in London, where the Pulitzer Prize-winning musical “Next to Normal” is belatedly having its British debut 14 years after it opened to acclaim on Broadway. The local premiere at the intimate but important Donmar Warehouse runs through Oct. 7, and this engagement looks unlikely to be its last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Venice Film Festival: Adam Driver Calls Out Netflix and Amazon Amid Strikes
description: His film “Ferrari,” a big-budget indie from Michael Mann, is the kind of adult drama the major studios have shied away from.
content: The name placard on the dais said “A. Driver,” and if you’re making a Ferrari movie, you’d certainly better have one.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Detroit, a French Brasserie That Feels Like a Portal to Paris
description: Plus: a recycled cashmere capsule collection, a new Brooklyn haunt inspired by Korean cafe culture — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: The Brazilian artist Wanda Pimentel’s “Envolvimento” paintings (1968-84) are hard-edged domestic vignettes — kitchens, bathrooms, the insides of cars — rendered in a lean, almost festive palette of mostly reds, greens and yellows. In these claustrophobic spaces, feminine-seeming thighs, ankles, feet and hands make fetishistic cameos, jutting out at awkward angles or lingering near water puddles and toilet-paper rolls. Sometimes, they’re framed by thick, windowpane-like lines that cast the viewer as a peeping Tom. “The house is not only a space of intimacy but also of fear,” says Alexandre Gabriel of São Paulo’s Fortes D’Aloia & Gabriel gallery, which will present Pimentel’s work at the Independent 20th Century art fair in New York City next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Byerly
title: What Courtney Dauwalter Learned in the Pain Cave
description: The agony of running ultramarathons is bearable, she discovered — even instructive, if you think about it the right way. And she learned how to win as few have ever won before.
content: After running for 60 miles through snow, up steep, root-filled switchbacks with thousands of feet of elevation gain, Courtney Dauwalter entered what she calls her pain cave. For the next 40 miles of the Western States 100-Mile Endurance Run through California’s Sierra Nevada, she imagined she was holding a chisel and chipping away at the furthest reaches of her pain, while staying focused on every step she took. By the time Dauwalter crossed the finish line in 15 hours, 29 minutes and 33 seconds, she had obliterated the women’s course record by more than an hour and had run the 23rd-fastest time, by anyone, in the race’s 45-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W. M. Akers
title: All That Glitters: A Fresh Look at the California Gold Rush
description: In “Fortune’s Frenzy,” Eilene Lyon traces the hardship and misery endured by Henry Jenkins, a stalwart Indiana farmer who, along with thousands of others, journeyed to California in 1851.
content: How do we remember the forty-niners? The hundreds of thousands of gold miners who flooded California, displaced Indigenous people, remade the landscape and laid the ground for statehood? Perhaps we picture a grizzled prospector panning for gold, broke and desperate, praying for the mother lode. Whatever we imagine, according to a new book by Eilene Lyon, the reality was much worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Belcher
title: An Emerging Thai Artist Explores the Subjectivity of Memory
description: Prae Pupityastaporn is one of 10 artists featured in Frieze Seoul’s Focus Asia section. Her landscape diptychs are being shown by the Thai gallery Nova Contemporary.
content: Sometimes a painting can be adjusted slightly and suddenly take on a new meaning for the artist. For Prae Pupityastaporn, a Thai landscape painter whose works are being presented at Frieze Seoul by the Nova Contemporary gallery in Bangkok, working with two similar paintings side by side can depict the delicate balance between memory and the present moment. An image can change ever so slightly, and ever so profoundly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: In Iowa, Pence Preaches Old-School Conservatism to a Dwindling Flock
description: The former vice president’s time in the spotlight at the debate did not lift his position in the polls, where he continues to languish in the low-single digits.
content: Mike Pence sat on Wednesday in a cavernous machine shop that was humming with activity as he preached old-time Republican religion: the dangers of the swelling national debt, the need to overhaul Social Security and Medicare, the perils of price controls on prescription drugs and the necessity of projecting military might across the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Teenager Who Rang Wrong Doorbell Faces Homeowner Who Shot Him
description: Ralph Yarl, a Black teenager, testified in court on Thursday about being shot on a man’s doorstep. A judge ruled that the charges against the white homeowner could proceed.
content: Ralph Yarl spoke softly but firmly as he recounted the April night when he rang the wrong doorbell and was met with gunfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: Review: In the ‘Ernest & Celestine’ Sequel, a Prodigal Cub Returns
description: The delightful odd couple of the Oscar-nominated French film head to the mountains in “A Trip to Gibberitia.” Every frame brims with painterly detail.
content: One of the many enduring pleasures of “Ernest & Celestine,” the 2014 French film about the unlikely bond between a bear and a mouse, is its rhapsodic bridging of music and imagery. The tale (based on books by Gabrielle Vincent) is rendered with gossamer line drawings so wedded to their accompanying score that the images sometimes ripple, swell and curl in tandem with the musical notes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman
title: The End (of Summer) Is Nigh. Let’s Enjoy It!
description: We’re not done: Savor these last few weeks of summer with dance parties, a vegan festival and more.
content: Here’s the bad news: On Aug. 11, the sun in New York City set at 8 p.m. It will not set that late again until 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Benjamin Mueller
title: McConnell Releases Letter Declaring Him ‘Medically Clear’ to Work After Episode
description: The brief statement came from the attending physician of Congress, who said he had reached the conclusion after consulting with the top Republican’s doctors and didn’t say he had examined the senator.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, on Thursday released a letter from the attending physician of Congress pronouncing him “medically clear” to continue his schedule as planned, a day after the Kentucky Republican froze up suddenly at a news conference in what appeared to be a medical episode similar to one he had on camera last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Retinol Has Many Skin Benefits. Here’s How to Use It.
description: To counter the signs of aging or treat acne, start slow and be patient.
content: Over-the-counter retinol products are popular for good reason: In addition to helping to control acne, they can improve the overall appearance of skin and lessen the signs of aging. They “are perfect for reducing fine lines and large pores, improving skin texture and evening out skin tone,” said Dr. Hope Mitchell, a dermatologist in Perrysburg, Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Patricia Mazzei and Jacey Fortin
title: After the Storm, a Cherished Local Fishing Industry Feels More Fragile
description: The fate of the fishing industry in Florida’s Big Bend region felt uncertain after Hurricane Idalia wrecked boats and turned pristine waters dark and dirty.
content: Dan Ellison started shrimping when he was 12, bringing a change of clothes on the boat so he could make it to school after early-morning outings. He would sketch shrimp boats in class, before quitting school in eighth grade to pursue his passion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Remarks on Diversity Lead to Investigation of North Carolina Judge
description: A justice of the North Carolina Supreme Court is being investigated by a state judicial commission after saying a report of bias in the judiciary should be examined.
content: When an online legal newsmagazine asked North Carolina Supreme Court Justice Anita S. Earls in June about a state report showing that most lawyers appearing before the court were white men, she said the court should examine the reasons for that disparity and address what she called implicit bias in the judiciary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve M. Kahn
title: When Advertisements Were Art
description: A show of commercial Art Deco posters opens later this month in Manhattan.
content: Between the 1920s and World War II, illustrators and designers slashed bands of color across advertisements to tempt consumers with ever faster modes of travel and cleverer machinery. The era’s frenetic pace of change is vividly represented in posters hung throughout the homes of the collectors William and Elaine Crouse, and they have partly denuded their walls to lend 58 pieces to “Art Deco: Commercializing the Avant-Garde,” an exhibition that opens Sept. 28 at Poster House in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Archer
title: Millennials Embrace Bicentennial Style
description: For a growing number of designers, dealers and collectors in their thirties, American antiques are hot.
content: Scroll through Erick J. Espinoza’s Instagram feed, and you might think you’ve traveled back in time to the 1930s — not the Art Deco version, but the version filled with hooked rugs, weathervanes and candlesticks betokening the era’s American Colonial Revival, perhaps with the color saturation cranked way up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan and Nate Schweber
title: Gang Member Pleads Guilty in Killing of 2 Long Island Teenagers
description: The girls, Kayla Cuevas, 16, and Nisa Mickens, 15, were killed in 2016 by Enrique Portillo and two other members of MS-13, prosecutors said.
content: One night in September 2016, two teenage girls were walking down a street in the Long Island hamlet of Brentwood when they were spotted by four members of MS-13, a violent transnational gang with Salvadoran roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Crime Is Nonpartisan
description: Cities and states run by Republicans do not actually have less crime.
content: Republican politicians often treat it as an established fact: Where they are in power, crime is low. Where Democrats are in power, crime is high.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
description: A selection from Hyperion’s now-streaming catalog, the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra’s Tchaikovsky and Yunchan Lim’s Liszt are among the highlights.
content: Hyperion has for decades been one of the most respected labels in classical music. But we’ve never been able to include it in this monthly column because its albums have not been available to stream — until now. After being acquired by Universal earlier this year, the company began putting past and fresh titles on Spotify and other platforms at the end of July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Dutch E-Bike Brand VanMoof Bought Out of Bankruptcy by Scooter Maker
description: Lavoie, which makes high-end scooters based on McLaren’s Formula 1 technology, acquired the trendy e-bike brand that had gained a zealous following.
content: VanMoof, the Dutch e-bike maker that gained a zealous following but declared bankruptcy last month, has been acquired by Lavoie, an upscale electric scooter company, the firms announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: It can be hard, sometimes, to keep in mind the distinction between weather — what’s it doing outside today? — and climate: What do statistical models suggest it’s likely to be doing decades from now? That confusion plays into the hands of oil companies and others who have long used pleasant days (weather) to downplay the threat of global warming (climate), as if a diseased patient can’t feel perfectly good some of the time. So David Lipsky’s new book, “The Parrot and the Igloo,” is a useful corrective; all the more so since Lipsky is a journalist rather than a climate scientist, whose aim is to gather the known facts about climate change and denialism into a compelling narrative that’s easy to grasp. Whether you’re bracing for a hurricane or lolling on the hammock ahead of Labor Day, maybe add that one to your reading list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Panorama of Design
description: A look at design-world events, products and people.
content: The approximately 40 designers represented in “Life Cycles: The Materials of Contemporary Design,” which opens at the Museum of Modern Art on Saturday, work with materials that can repair themselves, or be transformed from waste into refined objects, or represent a marriage of advanced technology and traditional craft. Their goal is to narrow the gap between the ideals of design and the realities of mass manufacturing, with its many human and environmental threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and John Liu
title: China’s Disinformation Fuels Anger Over Fukushima Water Release
description: By exaggerating the risks from Japan’s discharge of treated wastewater, Beijing hopes to cast Japan and its allies as conspirators in malfeasance, analysts say.
content: In Guangdong Province, on China’s southern coast, a woman posted a photo of a boxed-up Japanese-brand air-conditioner that she planned to return in protest. In southwest China, the owner of a Japanese pub posted a video of himself ripping down anime posters and smashing bottles, saying he planned to reopen the business as a Chinese bistro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: The Dirtiest Corners of New York City
description: A study examined 311 complaints to isolate the ZIP codes with the most.
content: People complain about garbage, and who can blame them? A new study by HouseFresh aimed to find the “dirtiest” cities in the United States by analyzing 12.3 million sanitation-related complaints made to 311 systems across the country. The complaints, made from Oct. 23, 2021 to Oct. 23, 2022, were tallied in cities with populations of more than 250,000, with adequate 311 data that could be mapped to specific ZIP codes. This left out some large cities — Denver, Las Vegas and Phoenix among them. The remaining 26 cities were ranked based on the number of sanitation complaints per 100,000 residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Yale’s President Announces He Will Step Down
description: Peter Salovey has increased the university’s endowment and its diversity. But the school faces the end of affirmative action and a push to end legacy admissions.
content: Peter Salovey, the president of Yale, announced Thursday that he will step down in June after 11 years in office, during which he increased the university’s endowment,  student enrollment, and its racial, ethnic and economic diversity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Oprah and Dwayne Johnson Give $10 Million to Help Maui Wildfire Victims
description: The stars helped establish the People’s Fund of Maui, which will give direct payments of $1,200 a month to residents displaced by the wildfires.
content: Oprah Winfrey and Dwayne Johnson have donated $10 million to help establish a fund that will give direct cash assistance to Maui residents displaced by catastrophic wildfires that destroyed hundreds of homes on the island, they said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A Resurgent Labour Party Sees Scotland as a Springboard to Power
description: As the Scottish nationalists stumble, a by-election near Glasgow this fall will test support for the opposition Labour party ahead of Britain’s coming general election.
content: For Britain’s opposition Labour Party, the road to 10 Downing Street is likely to run through Scotland. And the first steps on that road lie in a cluster of commuter towns southeast of Glasgow, where Labour is trying to win over swing voters like Cara Scott, in a closely watched parliamentary vote that will test the party’s appeal ahead of a coming general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan and Joshua Needelman
title: Weed at the U.S. Open? Some Players Swear They Can Smell It
description: The smell of marijuana is drifting over Court 17. The explanation appears to have nothing to do with tennis.
content: Those familiar with New York City know it’s a place where you will occasionally be confronted with the smell of marijuana. But when some of the world’s most elite tennis players caught a whiff of weed during opening day of the U.S. Open in Queens, an investigation was launched to find the possible source.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: What Happens if Mitch McConnell Retires Before His Senate Term Ends?
description: The longtime Republican leader froze up during a news conference on Wednesday in Kentucky. The second such episode in recent weeks, it stirred speculation about his future in the Senate.
content: For the second time in a little over a month, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the longtime Republican leader, froze up during a news conference on Wednesday, elevating concerns about his health and his ability to complete his term that ends in January 2027.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: How to Win at Monopoly
description: Pro tip: Don’t sleep on the red and orange properties. Players land on them the most.
content: When I look back at my child-rearing years, one of the most enduring emotions I felt — besides intense love and sleep deprivation — was absolute dread when my kids brought out the Monopoly set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Choose Love’ Review: Pick Your Own Cliché
description: This interactive Netflix rom-com lets viewers make choices on behalf of the main character, changing the story. But each path is banal.
content: Netflix’s latest interactive movie, “Choose Love,” is an attempt to apply a dating simulator experience to a standard-issue rom-com. Its choose-your-own-adventure interface — like the one in the 2019 “Black Mirror” movie “Bandersnatch,” another Netflix production — allows viewers to make decisions for Cami Conway (Laura Marano), a young woman who suddenly finds herself having to choose between three suitors. The choices that viewers select with the click of a button (Should Cami kiss this man or dodge his advances? Should she wear this dress or that one?) will ultimately inform which guy she ends up with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asmaa Elkeurti, Ana Ley and Juan Arredondo
title: Elevators at Most Subway Stations? ‘I’ll Believe It When I See It.’
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has vowed to make the city’s public transit system easier to navigate, but said it will take 32 years. For disabled New Yorkers, the subway is still a nightmare.
content: New York City’s subway system is a maze of obstructions for people who have difficulty walking. About one out of 15 New Yorkers has an ambulatory disability, according to Census Bureau data, but the vast majority of stations lack elevators and ramps, making much of the city hard to access for the hundreds of thousands of residents who rely on them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keri Blakinger
title: The Dungeons & Dragons Players of Death Row
description: For a group of men in a Texas prison, the fantasy game became a lifeline — to their imaginations, and to one another.
content: The first time Tony Ford played Dungeons & Dragons, he was a wiry Black kid who had never seen the inside of a prison. His mother, a police officer in Detroit, had quit the force and moved the family to West Texas. To Ford, it seemed like a different world. Strangers talked funny, and El Paso was half desert. But he could skateboard in all that open space, and he eventually befriended a nerdy white kid with a passion for Dungeons & Dragons. Ford fell in love with the role-playing game right away; it was complex and cerebral, a saga you could lose yourself in. And in the 1980s, everyone seemed to be playing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harvey Araton
title: What the N.B.A. May Need: a Soccer-Style Way to Banish Bad Teams
description: Dave Checketts, a former Knicks executive, has seen firsthand the emotional, and financial, power of relegation through his post-N.B.A. career in European soccer.
content: Dave Checketts believed he had experienced pretty much everything in his decades-long career as a sports executive. As the Knicks’ president, he had hired Pat Riley as coach in 1991, launching a memorable decade of championship contention at Madison Square Garden. As a founding owner of an M.L.S. franchise in Salt Lake City with his company, SCP Worldwide, he had negotiated a partnership with Real Madrid that helped to produce one of the early soccer-specific stadiums in the United States and an M.L.S. Cup title in 2009.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Moffitt
title: On Fire Island, a Home for Art — and the Artists Who Make It
description: How a New York homeowner and a pair of gay architects turned a midcentury Sears catalog kit house in the Pines into a contemporary refuge that looks nothing like its neighbors.
content: THERE’S A DISTINCT palette to Fire Island Pines, the gay beach getaway a two-hour train ride from New York City. Boxy houses and boardwalks made of untreated cedar have gone gray from the salt air. Pale sand dunes covered in sea grass and holly trees are muted against the men in neon swim briefs who wander through them. But one house stands out amid the uniformity: a modest, 1,100-square-foot white two-bedroom with a gently peaked roof, its walls filled with colorful contemporary art. Architecturally, it looks like it belongs in Palm Springs; its contents would be at home in any Manhattan gallery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lotte L.S
title: Poem: From ‘This Energy Wasted by Flight —’
description: A domestic scene where the home is not a place of safety or comfort but a site of labor.
content: This selection from a longer poem by Lotte L.S. conjures a domestic scene, emerging out of memory. A home’s tattered, broken and neglected objects accumulate, and as they do, the demands of these objects become apparent. A mess is not inert. Dirty dishes make demands. The home here is not a place of safety or comfort but a site of labor. Yet there is no strike — only escape. Selected by Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Malin
title: Overlooked No More: Chick Strand, Pioneering Experimental Filmmaker
description: Often turning her lens on women, she emerged as one of independent cinema’s fiercest proponents on the West Coast.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Judge Temporarily Blocks Texas Law That Would Restrict Drag Shows
description: If a permanent order is issued later, the ruling would most likely be appealed by the state.
content: A federal judge on Thursday temporarily blocked a new Texas law that would restrict drag shows, a victory for L.G.B.T.Q. groups that have criticized the measure as an attack against drag performers and organizers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: For John Green, the Battle Over Access to Books Has Gotten Personal
description: A fight over Green’s books in his home state of Indiana reflects a broader cultural debate over what books are appropriate for young readers, and who gets to decide.
content: For about as long as he’s been a published author, John Green has faced efforts to censor his books. His debut novel, “Looking for Alaska,” a coming-of-age story that includes references to drug use and sex, has been challenged in schools for at least 15 years, and has frequently landed on the American Library Association’s most banned books list. Last year, it received more than 50 challenges in schools across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Lange
title: Some Old-Fashioned Home-Design Manuals Are Worth Revisiting
description: Design experts say a surprising number of them have stood the test of time.
content: In 1868, the designer Charles Eastlake published “Hints on Household Taste,” a popular guide to outfitting the home in good taste, from the street front to the china cupboard and all the rooms in between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Tropical Storm Jose Is Expected to Be Absorbed by Hurricane Franklin
description: Jose formed on Thursday morning. It’s now the third named storm in the Atlantic, along with Idalia and Franklin.
content: As the remnants of Idalia battered the coast of North Carolina, and while Hurricane Franklin churned far off in the Atlantic, Tropical Storm Jose formed early Thursday, becoming the latest named storm of the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Taylor Swift Eras Tour Concert Film Coming to Movie Theaters
description: A theatrical version of the billion-dollar tour — a cultural juggernaut that just ended its North American leg — opens Oct. 13.
content: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour, the billion-dollar juggernaut that has dominated the cultural calendar this year, may be on a break before picking up internationally, but its momentum will only rest so long: The show is coming to movie theaters this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Mooj Zadie, Shannon Lin, Rikki Novetsky, Lisa Chow, John Ketchum, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: A Major Overhaul of Prescription Drug Prices
description: A negotiation program is projected to save the government tens of billions of dollars in the coming years.
content: A year ago, Congress overhauled how drugs for older Americans are paid for, giving Medicare the power to bargain with drug makers over prices. It’s the biggest change to health care for more than a decade, and this week, the Biden administration began to implement it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Thursday Briefing
description: Drone attacks in the war in Ukraine.
content: Exploding drones were launched into six regions of Russia overnight on Wednesday, Russian officials said, damaging military cargo planes at an airfield 30 miles from the border with Estonia, a NATO member, in an apparent sign that Ukraine was increasingly capable of striking back deep inside Moscow’s territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Scenes From Johannesburg: A Deadly Fire Downtown Kills Scores
description: The blaze struck an abandoned building that had become a crowded squatter settlement. The authorities were investigating the cause.
content: A fire consumed a crowded five-story building in downtown Johannesburg early on Thursday, tearing through an informal settlement of homeless people in what was being described as one of the deadliest blazes in South African history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Wall Street Moguls Win Important Backer in Their Fight Over Hedge Fund Sale
description: A group of high-profile investors is pushing to buy a storied hedge fund that has already agreed to be sold to another firm.
content: A coterie of high-profile investors, including Bill Ackman of Pershing Square, Boaz Weinstein of Saba Capital Management and Marc Lasry of Avenue Capital Group, is pushing to buy Sculptor Capital, the successor to the storied hedge fund Och-Ziff — even though the fund has already agreed to sell itself to another investment firm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Tooze
title: Joe Biden’s First Term and the ‘West Wing’ Fantasy of American Politics
description: In “The Last Politician,” Franklin Foer presents the first half of Biden’s presidency as a series of made-for-television moments meant to inspire doubters and assuage critics.
content: How will the history of the Biden administration be written: as the turning point when America began to heal or as a hiatus between moments of deadlock and adversity? Franklin Foer’s “The Last Politician,” an account of Biden’s first two years in office, is the first draft of an answer. It has the makings of high drama. Crisis follows crisis. The problem is that, from Biden’s bleak inauguration to the surprise result of the midterms, we know the story in advance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation and Consumers Show Staying Power as Fed Eyes Another Rate Move
description: Overall inflation climbed to 3.3 percent, from 3 percent previously, underscoring the Fed’s long road back to 2 percent price increases.
content: The Federal Reserve has warned for months that wrestling rapid inflation back to a normal pace was likely to be a bumpy process, a reality underscored by fresh data on Thursday that showed a closely watched inflation gauge picking back up in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso and Alicia Napierkowski
title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: This week’s properties are five-bedroom homes in Westport, Conn., and White Plains, N.Y.
content: A five-bedroom, three-full-and-two-half-bath, 4,498-square-foot house built circa 1929, with a screened front porch; a kitchen with an island and high-end appliances; a great room with high ceilings, wood beams, a Rumford stone fireplace and porch access; a primary en suite bedroom with high ceilings, walk-in closets and a bathroom with radiant-heat floors and double sinks; a wing with a kitchenette, living area and en suite bedroom; a mudroom, laundry room and office; a basement with a cedar closet and a Pilates room; a landscaped yard, a three-car attached garage with an EV charging station and a radiant-heat driveway, on 0.45 acres on a cul-de-sac. Michael Chait, William Pitt Julia B Fee Sotheby’s International, 203-243-1995; williampitt.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby, Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon
title: Why the Johannesburg Apartment Building Was a Firetrap
description: A visit and imagery of the five-story building show that it had a litany of major safety issues that made it vulnerable to a deadly fire.
content: It may take time to determine what started an apartment fire in Johannesburg early Thursday morning and why more than 70 people died. But witness accounts, imagery of the blaze and a visit to the site in May indicate that the five-story building had a litany of major safety issues that made it vulnerable to a deadly fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘We Kill for Love’ Review: What They Did in Hollywood’s Shadows
description: This documentary explores a narrow genre of direct-to-VHS soft-core thrillers that found a niche with the advent of video rentals and home viewing.
content: If “Boogie Nights” had a villain, it was videotape. For the characters, the arrival of that technology put an end to a golden age of pornographic movies and spoiled the illusion that they were making art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Drill, Baby, Drill: The Promise of Geothermal Power
description: Techniques developed by Big Oil may lead to the next clean energy breakthrough.
content: Clean energy has become synonymous with wind and solar, and with good reason. Thanks to improved technology and declining costs, wind turbines and solar panels are producing a rapidly growing share of the world’s electricity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: As Migrant Crisis Worsens, New York Leaders Pressure Biden to Do More
description: A broad coalition of civic, business and union leaders has come together to apply pressure on Washington to help with the migrant crisis in New York.
content: After months of mostly working behind the scenes, a force of municipal, business and labor leaders in New York has begun a public campaign to highlight how they believe Washington has failed to adequately address the migrant crisis that has overwhelmed the city in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Fremont’ Review: Rapid Transit
description: This dry, understated film follows a young Afghan refugee looking for connection in her new home, the San Francisco Bay Area.
content: “Fremont” takes its title from the Bay Area city of the same name. Often called Little Kabul, it’s home to one of the largest enclaves of Afghans in the United States, with many immigrants gravitating toward it for a sense of community. That’s what Donya (Anaita Wali Zada) is searching for: Community. Connection. Love. These are difficult pursuits for anyone in these atomized times, but especially for Donya, a young refugee and former translator for the American military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: At the U.S. Open, Alex Michelsen Is Growing Up Fast
description: Michelsen, a 19-year-old American who passed on the University of Georgia to turn pro, has raced up the rankings since January and should break into the top 100 after his run in New York.
content: Things some teenagers do that make adults crazy: spending too much time on devices, leaving dirty dishes in the sink and sending hard backhands down the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: A Record Crowd Shows Buildup of Nebraska Volleyball and Women’s Sports
description: Nebraska garnered more than 92,000 fans for a regular-season match held in its football stadium.
content: As the Nebraska women’s volleyball team strolled out of the tunnel for its most unusual home match, “Sirius” by the Alan Parsons Project, the walkout song for the 1990s Chicago Bulls, blared over the stadium loudspeakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: An Architect Who Forges Ahead in Her Own Lane
description: Elizabeth Graziolo is a Black female classical architect and owns her own firm. Thanks to her influence, she may soon have more company.
content: The University of Notre Dame is known for producing top-notch classically trained young architects, and every year the principals of architecture firms that work in traditional styles make pilgrimages to a spring career fair at the Indiana school to vie for the new talent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Justice Thomas Reports Private Trips With Harlan Crow
description: Justices Clarence Thomas and Samuel A. Alito Jr. had asked for extensions on their annual forms that show travel, gifts and other financial information.
content: Justice Clarence Thomas, in his annual financial disclosure form released Thursday, responded in detail to reports that he had failed to disclose luxury trips, flights on a private jet and a real estate transaction with a Texas billionaire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Energy Dept. Announces $12 Billion to Help Factories Convert to Electric Cars
description: The grants and loans, provided under the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act, are meant to keep autoworkers’ jobs in their communities.
content: The Energy Department announced on Thursday that it had made $2 billion in grants and $10 billion in loans available to auto companies to convert existing factories that build gas-powered cars and trucks into plants that produce hybrid and electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: The Photographer Who Immortalized British Viceroys and Maharajahs
description: Raja Deen Dayal’s portraits of Indian royalty and the British colonial elite are stunning documents of the beginnings of photography.
content: In 1887, a photographer named Lala Deen Dayal took a picture of Frederick Temple-Blackwood, First Marquess of Dufferin and Ava. The men were in Shimla, in the foothills of the Himalayas, because the British colonial government in India moved there every summer to escape the heat of Kolkata. Dufferin was the British viceroy, and Dayal, who had worked as a surveyor for the colonial government before leaving to pursue his passion as a freelancer, was his official photographer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ethan Tate
title: Why Can’t a Cemetery Have the Hottest Painting in Town?
description: Forest Lawn’s museum director and resident art historian, James Fishburne, has re-envisioned a storied panorama painting, with a theatrical show and slick animations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
title: At Refuge for Desperate Families, Deadly Fire Was ‘Waiting to Happen’
description: Johannesburg, with a severe shortage of affordable housing, has hundreds of illegally occupied derelict buildings that officials and housing advocates say have become firetraps.
content: They arrived in desperation, unable to find anything better, safer or cheaper in a city with a severe shortage of affordable housing. They settled in a trash-choked building owned and neglected by the city of Johannesburg, paying “rent” to criminals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: People Are More Generous Than You May Think
description: People are driven by a lot more than self-interest.
content: Are human beings fundamentally good or fundamentally bad? Are people mostly generous, or are they mostly selfish?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Maestro Accused of Striking Singer Withdraws From Performances
description: John Eliot Gardiner said he would take time off until next year to “get the specialist help I recognize that I have needed for some time.”
content: The renowned conductor John Eliot Gardiner, who drew criticism this month when he was accused of hitting a singer in the face after a performance in France, said on Thursday that he would withdraw from performances for the rest of the year as he sought counseling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Inflation Rate in Eurozone Holds Steady
description: Prices rose at an annual rate of 5.3 percent, defying expectations of a slowdown. The news may bolster the case for another European Central Bank interest rate increase.
content: Consumer prices in the eurozone rose 5.3 percent in August compared with a year earlier, sticking at the same pace as the previous month and defying economists’ expectations for a slowdown, according to an initial estimate by the statistics agency of the European Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: 5 Stand-Up Specials to Stream for the Labor Day Weekend
description: Todd Barry, Tracy Morgan, Sasheer Zamata, Chris Fleming and Jason Fried riff on weird characters, middle age, lost histories and more.
content: Todd Barry speaks fluent sarcasm. After decades of refinement, honing his low-key deadpan into something flexible and distinctive, he can turn a sentence inside-out with the mildest shift in intonation, instantly divorcing what he says from what he means. The pivots in his jokes are subtle but crisp. Ever since David Letterman retired from late night, sarcasm has no better champion. Barry starts waving its flag as soon as the applause settles down on his very funny new special. “That is the type of forced fraudulent crowd response that will propel this whole show,” he says, enough of a hint of a smile to soften the blow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher
title: The U.S. and China Are Talking Again. Where It Will Lead Is Unclear.
description: Gina Raimondo, the U.S. commerce secretary, and her Chinese counterparts agreed to continue economic talks, but such dialogues have a disheartening record.
content: When Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, visited China this week, she joined a long line of U.S. politicians who have come to the country to try to sway Chinese officials to open their market to foreign businesses and buy more American exports, in addition to other goals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Bringing Your Own Cheese to the Cookout
description: Is it rude to accommodate your own preference for toppings?
content: My husband’s family rarely has cheese for burgers at cookouts. One or two family members (out of eight to 10 who are normally at any gathering) do not like cheese, so it’s not readily kept around. I love a good cheeseburger. My husband agrees that the lack of cheese is weird but says it would be rude if I brought my own. Please rule that I can bring my own cheese to these cookouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: UBS Gets a $29 Billion Bump From M.&A. Accounting
description: The Swiss bank’s sharply discounted takeover of Credit Suisse led to a paper gain that gave it the biggest quarterly profit by a bank in history.
content: When UBS agreed to buy its archrival, Credit Suisse, for a little over $3 billion this spring at the Swiss government’s behest, analysts and investors said that price represented a steep discount. UBS’s latest financial results reflect just how much of a steal it was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Jason Gutierrez
title: Fire in a Garment Printing Shop Kills at Least 15 in the Philippines
description: Employees, the business owner and some of his relatives were among the dead at the shop near Manila. The cause of the blaze was unknown.
content: A fire in a house that was being used as a T-shirt printing shop in the Philippines killed at least 15 people on Thursday, including its workers, the business owner and his family members, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Khoury
title: You Know You’re Getting Old When Your Bartenders Retire
description: Two longtime New York City bartenders, “Joe” Petrsoric and Kevin Duffy Philzone, were dependable anchors in our ever-changing, once-nocturnal city.
content: I ducked into Sardi’s on a recent Wednesday and made my way up to the second-floor bar. While the matinee lunch crowd began to fill the downstairs dining room, I slipped onto a bar stool upstairs and waited to speak with Joe, the New York City bartender who would retire in a couple of days after 55 years at the Theater District mainstay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Keith Spicer, Canada’s Offbeat Envoy of Reconciliation, Dies at 89
description: As the country’s first commissioner of official languages, he oversaw a dual-language mandate. He later led a task force to listen to Canadians’ complaints.
content: Keith Spicer, who as a spirited government official pushed his fellow Canadians to define their national identity and reconcile their bilingual heritage more than two centuries after the British defeated the French to capture Quebec, died on Aug. 24 in Ottawa. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yelena Moroz Alpert
title: Look! Up on the Wall! It’s a Golf Ball! It’s a Starfish! It’s Plaster!
description: Designers and fabricators are finding new forms for the ornamental material.
content: If Beth Cayre had to move, she would regret leaving the dining room ceiling, with its plaster cherry blossom branches hand molded by the ceramics artist Matthew Solomon. And who could blame her?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Choosing Hospice Care, as Jimmy Carter Did
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about the former president’s well-publicized choice. Also: Our election system; G.O.P. debate; the magic of camp.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: Republicans Are Neither Internationalist Nor Isolationist. They’re Asia First.
description: The G.O.P. candidates may disagree about Ukraine but they’re united in who they think the real enemy is.
content: At first glance, last week’s Republican presidential debate revealed a party fractured over America’s role in the world. Ron DeSantis said he wouldn’t support additional aid to Ukraine unless Europe does more. Vivek Ramaswamy said he wouldn’t arm Ukraine no matter what. Chris Christie, Mike Pence and Nikki Haley, all staunch defenders of Kyiv, pounced. Within minutes, the altercations were so intense that the moderators struggled to regain control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kendall Waldman
title: 4 Days, 690 Miles, Countless Stalls: Behold the ‘World’s Longest Yard Sale’
description: Everyone loves a bargain. But can anyone survive the entirety of the 127 Yard Sale, an annual four-day event that stretches from Michigan to Alabama?
content: To the visitor driving in from out of state, the 127 Yard Sale seems like a kind of Ironman for thrifters. The “world’s longest yard sale” is a test of endurance and attention. Spanning six states, 690 miles and thousands of stalls, it traverses dramatic landscapes, delicate cultural terrain and two time zones. Seeing it all in the four allotted days — Aug. 3 to 6 this year — is enough to induce vertigo in even the most stable-minded deal hunter. But some of us are foolish enough to try anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: Is It Time to Negotiate With Putin?
description: We’re past the “fairy tale stage” of the war in Ukraine. How does it end?
content: It’s been 18 months since Russia invaded Ukraine. No true negotiations have happened. As the stalemate continues, what role should the United States play in the fight?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Summer Ends, but Corn Is Forever
description: In cold sesame noodles with crisp cucumber, creamy corn soup with basil, and farro salad with crispy chickpeas.
content: When I stepped out for coffee this morning, I was met with the most welcome surprise: crisp, 65-degree air and a breeze stiff enough to make me wonder if I’d be too chilly in shorts. I blissfully strolled to my neighborhood cafe and ordered the first hot latte I’d had in six months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendy Moonan
title: A Ship Captain’s House in Seattle, via Norway, Finds New Life
description: The house, a historical landmark that was built in 1933 with cedar shingles and Douglas fir paneling, receives a respectful kitchen addition.
content: Six years ago, Sonya Schneider and her husband, Stuart Nagae, bought a federally designated historical landmark in Seattle, a 5,000-square-foot, two-story home sheathed in dark, old-growth Western cedar shingles, with multiple gables, dormer windows and a cedar-shake roof. It sat on an unusually large three-quarter-acre lot with mature maples, Douglas fir and a hemlock tree, in Ballard, an old Seattle neighborhood on Puget Sound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Biden Administration Proposes Expanding Background Checks on Gun Sales
description: The proposed rules are part of President Biden’s piecemeal efforts to enact a key policy goal, universal background checks, which has been repeatedly stymied by congressional Republicans.
content: The Biden administration on Thursday proposed the broadest expansion of firearms background checks in decades, leveraging a provision of the bipartisan gun control law passed last year that requires thousands of unlicensed firearms brokers to register as federally licensed dealers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Russeth
title: Ephemeral but Unforgettable: Korean Experimental Art Is Having a Star Turn
description: A Guggenheim exhibition shines a light on a remarkable but lesser-known art scene in South Korea that thrived in the tumult of the 1960s and 1970s.
content: The 1960s and 1970s were tumultuous in South Korea, with a military dictatorship pushing breakneck economic growth and suppressing civil rights. In the midst of this upheaval, young artists pursued radical projects.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Listen: Meeting A.O.C., Heavy Metal 101, Remembering Bob Barker
description: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
content: Audiophiles,

title: Follower of November

content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘One Piece’ Review: Netflix Tries to Translate the Anime Magic (Again)
description: Remember the live-action, English-language “Cowboy Bebop”?
content: With “One Piece,” Netflix repeats history, and there isn’t much evidence that it paid attention to what happened the first time around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh Bardugo
title: Falling in Love With the Avengers, America’s Most Toxic Work Force
description: One thing that drew Leigh Bardugo to the Avengers as a girl was that their turnover rate meant they were always hiring.
content: I bought my comics from a newsstand just a few blocks from our apartment in the San Fernando Valley. As a kid, I thought it was a big deal to walk those few blocks and buy something on my own. The newsstand was wedged between a pizza place and a beauty supply called the Bee Hive, and it was a little seedy. You were just as likely to see guys buying issues of Hustler as you were kids snapping up “X-Men.” But mostly you’d see men and women arrayed in a line, magazines in hand, backs slightly bowed, heads hanging as if too heavy for their necks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Vincler
title: When All the Art Is Green: Swiss Institute Takes On Climate Change
description: The artworks in “Spora,” a long-term exhibition in Manhattan, are easy to overlook, but they bring an acute awareness to the environment beyond the gallery doors.
content: Art cannot save us. This is the problem with art that seeks to address climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K. Replaces Defense Secretary Ben Wallace With Grant Shapps
description: Mr. Wallace, a former soldier, had come to symbolize Britain’s steadfast support for Ukraine in the war against Russia.
content: The British government said on Thursday that it would replace its departing defense secretary, Ben Wallace, a former soldier who was respected in the White House and Pentagon and came to symbolize Britain’s steadfast support for Ukraine in the war against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Catch the final installment of “How To With John Wilson.” Or check out a peppy football documentary and a mesmerizing cop show.
content: ‘How To With John Wilson’When to watch: Friday at 11 p.m., on HBO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: How an Engraver Straddles the Centuries
description: Andrew Raftery’s ceramics and wallpaper energize the laborious art of engraving to explore contemporary life.
content: When Andrew Raftery, a master engraver and professor of printmaking at the Rhode Island School of Design, decided to make wallpaper, he chose an 18th-century French format called domino — small sheets printed on a letterpress, which were originally produced by stationers as shelf paper and box liners.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In a Storied River on Vancouver Island, Fish Are Dying in Droves
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 31, 2023.
content: “This river is in the emergency room with a pile of doctors trying everything they can to keep that patient alive.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arlene Hirst
title: Design Classics of the Future
description: Experts suggest a few recent products that may stick around for generations to come.
content: What makes a design a classic? New products flood the market every year, yet very few have long lives and lasting impact. The lounge chair designed by Charles and Ray Eames is as coveted today as it was in 1956, the year it was introduced. (Probably even more so.) Richard Sapper’s Tizio table lamp has illuminated the work spaces of thousands of users who were born after it made its first appearance in 1971. Both products are enshrined in museums.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Treffinger
title: Advice for Making the Practical Pretty
description: On feel-good desk chairs, stylish laundry rooms and game tables you don’t have to banish to the basement.
content: I’m looking for a new, ergonomically correct desk chair — but I want it to look nice. Is that too much to ask?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Investigators Seize ‘Marcus Aurelius’ Statue From Cleveland Museum
description: The Manhattan district attorney’s office said the headless bronze, valued at $20 million, is a depiction of the Roman emperor and was looted from Turkey.
content: With its flowing robes and stoic posture, the larger-than-life bronze statue believed to represent the great Roman statesman Marcus Aurelius had, since 1986, held pride of place in the Greek and Roman galleries at the Cleveland Museum of Art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: How New York’s Public Hospitals Cut Carbon Emissions: More Vegetables
description: Making plant-based meals the default has reduced food-related greenhouse gas emissions by 36 percent, the mayor’s office said. Just don’t say “vegan.”
content: On the menu at New York City’s 11 public hospitals is pasta with Bolognese sauce, without the meat. Or Sancocho, a Latin American beef stew, minus the beef. Or maybe a black-eyed peas casserole with cornbread made without butter or eggs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Articulate Ignorance of Vivek Ramaswamy
description: What’s worse than voters who don’t understand how government works? Candidates who don’t.
content: As our nation continues its march to 2024, a year that will feature not only a presidential election but also potentially four criminal trials of the Republican front-runner, I’ve been thinking about the political and cultural power of leadership. How much do leaders matter, really? What role does corrupt political leadership play in degrading not just a government but the culture itself?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: UBS Reports Record-Breaking $29 Billion Profit
description: The huge gain stems from the bank’s acquisition of its rival Credit Suisse this spring for about $3.2 billion, a steep discount that is skewing its quarterly results.
content: When UBS agreed to buy its archrival Credit Suisse for a little over $3 billion this spring at the Swiss government’s behest, analysts and investors said that price represented a steep discount. UBS’s latest financial results reflect just how much of a steal it was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Does the MIND Diet Prevent Dementia?
description: Healthy eating might help protect your brain, experts say, but other factors play in as well.
content: If you’re concerned about developing dementia later in life, it’s natural to wonder if you might be able to prevent it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Is China in So Much Trouble?
description: When ideology gets in the way of the obvious solutions.
content: The narrative about China has changed with stunning speed, from unstoppable juggernaut to pitiful, helpless giant. How did that happen?

description: Do we know why Denzel Washington’s vigilante is in Italy? No. This third franchise installment just assumes you’re here for the entertaining violence.
content: As one does in Italy, Robert McCall likes to sit in a little cafe, watching the world pass by. McCall — an enigmatic avenger played by Denzel Washington — likes tea, but he’s fine with the coffee that a beautiful server brings him with a smile. People often smile at McCall, perhaps drawn to his looks, his quiet mien and the restrained intensity of his physicality, as if he were holding back a great and terrifying force. Or maybe, like the rest of us, they are trying to silently encourage McCall to just get on with it and start painting the town red.

content: If you’re looking for dessert ideas for a late-summer picnic, B. Dylan Hollis has you covered. The Bermuda-born, piano-playing, kitsch-collecting TikTok sensation would like to recommend a few alternatives — or perhaps accompaniments — to Popsicles. Consider Kiskadee Fantasy Pie, a 1950s classic named for the yellow-bellied songbird, consisting of whipped cream, pineapple and meringue layered on a saltine cracker crust; or Banana Marlow, a marshmallow-based ice-cream confection that was all the rage in the 1930s; or Grasshopper Pie.
